chapter.title: Additional OpenIDM Samples: Roles
chapter.para: OpenIDM includes two types of roles: default roles and custom managed roles, as defined in the OpenIDM Glossary.

For a discussion of how basic CRUD operations apply to roles, read the section on
Configuring Custom Roles.

section.title: Configuring OpenIDM for Roles and Provisioning
section.para: With OpenIDM roles, you can provision a set of attributes based on role membership.

In this sample, you will configure roles named Employee and Contractor. You will then assign a user to each of these roles. You can then observe the results on both the internal OpenIDM managed user repository and an external OpenDJ system.

In this sample, when you assign a user to the Employee role, the user becomes a member of two groups: Employees and Chat Users. In contrast, when you assign a user to the Contractor role, that user becomes a member of only the Contractor group.

section.title: External LDAP Configuration
section.para: Configure the LDAP server as for sample 2, LDAP Server Configuration. The LDAP user must have write access to create users from OpenIDM on the LDAP server. When you configure the LDAP server, import the appropriate LDIF file (openidm/samples/roles/provrole/data/Example.ldif).

section.title: Install the Sample
section.para: Prepare OpenIDM as described in Preparing OpenIDM, then start OpenIDM with the following configuration for the Roles and Provisioning sample.

section.title: Run the Sample
section.para: The sync.json configuration file for this sample includes two mappings: systemLdapAccounts_managedUser, which synchronizes users from the source LDAP server with the target OpenIDM repository; and managedUser_systemLdapAccounts, which synchronizes changes from the OpenIDM repository to the LDAP server.

You can run this part of the sample by using the curl command-line utility, or by using the OpenIDM Administration UI. This section provides instructions for both methods, in the following procedures:

procedure.title: Run the Sample Using the Command Line

step.para: Reconcile the repository over the REST interface by running the following command:
step.screen: $ curl \ --cacert self-signed.crt \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username: openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --header "Content-Type: application/json" \ --request POST \ "https://localhost:8443/openidm/recon?_action=recon&mapping=systemLdapAccounts_managedUser" { "_id" : "6402b04f-55ae-49a8-aa85-87d41607d256", "state": "ACTIVE" }
step.para: The reconciliation operation returns a reconciliation run ID and the status of the operation. Reconciliation creates user objects from LDAP in the OpenIDM repository, assigning the new objects random unique IDs.

The following steps include query filter syntax described in
Constructing Queries section as well as the
Supported Operations Appendix of the Integrator's Guide.
To retrieve the users and associated IDs from the repository, the following command queries their IDs, with output limited by _fields to userName and _id.

To retrieve an individual account object with specific data, include the ID in the URL, along with desired _field data. For example, the following command outputs three attributes associated with the noted UUID:
step.screen: $ curl \ --cacert self-signed.crt \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username: openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --request GET \ "https://localhost:8443/openidm/managed/user/86fa4740-b250-47ff-af46-515f544b468c?_fields=userName,roles,effectiveRoles" { "userName": "bjensen", "roles": [ "openidm-authorized" ], "effectiveRoles": [ "openidm-authorized" ] }

step.para: Create an Employee and a Contractor role with the following commands:
step.screen: $ curl \ --cacert self-signed.crt \ --header "Content-type: application/json" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username: openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --header "If-None-Match: *" \ --request PUT \ --data '{ "properties" : { "name" : "Employee", "description": "Role assigned to workers on the payroll." } }' \ https://localhost:8443/openidm/managed/role/Employee

$ curl \ --cacert self-signed.crt \ --header "Content-type: application/json" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username: openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --header "If-None-Match: *" \ --request PUT \ --data '{ "properties" : { "name" : "Contractor", "description": "Role assigned to contract workers." } }' \ https://localhost:8443/openidm/managed/role/Contractor
step.para: If you prefer a server-generated UUID for this role, you could create it with a POST request. For an example, see the following section: Creating A New Role with a REST Call.
Confirm that the roles now exist with the following command:
At this point, the "Employee" and "Contractor" roles are just labels. With the following command, you can add an assignments property to the "Employee"role:
When you assign the Employee role, you will see these attributes in the effectiveAssignments for the target user.
Before you can assign the Employee role to a user, you need to find the _id for that user. The following command finds the _id for user bjensen.
step.screen:
$ curl \ --cacert self-signed.crt \ --header "Content-type: application/json" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username: openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --request GET \ 'https://localhost:8443/openidm/managed/user?_queryFilter=/userName+eq+"bjensen"&_fields=_id'
{ "result" : [ { "_id" : "86fa4740-b250-47ff-af46-515f544b468c" } ], "resultCount" : 1, "pagedResultsCookie" : null, "remainingPagedResults" : -1 }
step.para:
For more information on the _queryFilter, see the following section:
Constructing Queries. Note the use of single quotes around the URL to avoid conflicts with the double quotes around user bjensen.
You can then use the _id to assign the Employee role to user bjensen:
step.screen: $ curl \ --cacert self-signed.crt \ --header "Content-Type: application/json" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username: openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --header "If-Match: *" \ --request PATCH \ --data '[ { "operation" : "add", "field" : "/roles/-", "value" : "managed/role/Employee" } ]' \ "https://localhost:8443/openidm/managed/user/86fa4740-b250-47ff-af46-515f544b468c"

step.para: Review the results for user bjensen. Note how the following command limits the search to that user with ?_queryFilter=/username+eq+"bjensen". Also note how the command limits the output to relevant fields with _fields=_id,userName,roles,effectiveRoles,effectiveAssignments:
If you see "effectiveAssignments" : null in the output you might have forgotten to PATCH the assignments property to the Employee role, as described in an earlier step.
You should also see that user bjensen has the elements of the assignments property in her "effectiveAssignments".
Examine the sync.json file in the samples/roles/provrole/conf directory. Note the following excerpt from the managedUser_systemLdapAccounts mapping:
That mapping should synchronize the employeeType attribute to the information for user bjensen in your instance of OpenDJ. To verify that analysis, run the following command:
step.screen: $ ldapsearch \ --port 1389 \ --hostname localhost \ --baseDN "dc=example,dc=com" \ --bindDN "cn=Directory Manager" \ --bindPassword - \ --searchScope sub uid=bjensen dn uid employeeType
step.para: You should be prompted for user 'cn=Directory Manager'. After you enter the password (which is password, by default), you should see the following output:
step.screen: dn: uid=bjensen,ou=People,dc=example,dc=com uid: bjensen employeeType: Employee

step.para: Now take the Employee role one step further. Add the groups that an Employee should be a member of in the remote data store, in this case, OpenDJ.

User the command that follows to add the noted "value" of the attribute assignment for groups under the assignments/ldap/attributes field. The output should include both attributes associated with the Employee role, including the employeeType attribute added previously.
Confirm that user bjensen is a member of the Chat User and Employee groups. Run the following command on the OpenDJ server:
step.screen: $ ldapsearch \ --port 1389 \ --hostname localhost \ --baseDN "dc=example,dc=com" \ --bindDN "cn=Directory Manager" \ --bindPassword - \ --searchScope sub uid=bjensen dn uid employeeType isMemberOf
step.para: After you confirm with the OpenDJ password, you should see the following output:

screen.computeroutput: dn: uid=bjensen,ou=People,dc=example,dc=com uid: bjensen employeeType: Employee isMemberOf: cn=openidm2,ou=Groups,dc=example,dc=com isMemberOf: cn=Employees,ou=Groups,dc=example,dc=com

step.para: You can verify the output with the following REST call to the system/ldap/account endpoint:
step.screen:
$ curl \ --cacert self-signed.crt \ --header "Content-Type: application/json" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username: openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --request GET \ 'https://localhost:8443/openidm/system/ldap/account?_queryFilter=/uid+sw+"bjensen"&_fields=dn,uid,employeeType,ldapGroups&_prettyPrint=true'
{ "result" : [ { "dn" : "uid=bjensen,ou=People,dc=example,dc=com", "uid" : "bjensen", "employeeType" : "Employee", "ldapGroups" : [ "cn=openidm2,ou=Groups,dc=example,dc=com", "cn=Employees,ou=Groups,dc=example,dc=com" ] } ], "resultCount" : 1, "pagedResultsCookie" : null, "remainingPagedResults" : -1 }

step.para: Now make similar changes to the Contractor role. The following command makes all associated changes in one PATCH add operation:
step.screen: $ curl \ --cacert self-signed.crt \ --header "Content-Type: application/json" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username: openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --header "If-Match: *" \ --request PATCH \ --data '[ { "operation" : "add", "field" : "/assignments/ldap/attributes", "value" : [{ "name": "ldapGroups", "value": [ "cn=Contractors,ou=Groups,dc=example,dc=com" ], "assignmentOperation" : "mergeWithTarget", "unassignmentOperation" : "removeFromTarget" }, { "name": "employeeType", "value": "Contractor", "assignmentOperation": "mergeWithTarget", "unassignmentOperation": "removeFromTarget" }] } ]' \ "https://localhost:8443/openidm/managed/role/Contractor"

step.para: To confirm the changes to the Contractor role, run the following command:

step.screen:
$ curl \ --cacert self-signed.crt \ --header "Content-Type: application/json" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username: openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --request GET \ 'https://localhost:8443/openidm/managed/user?_queryFilter=/userName+eq+"jdoe"&_fields=_id'
{ "result" : [ { "_id" : "0918e1ca-7d5e-473d-8b64-97f47cb606f6" } ], "resultCount" : 1, "pagedResultsCookie" : null, "remainingPagedResults" : -1 }

step.para: Now use that _id to assign user jdoe to the Contractors role:
step.screen: $ curl \ --insecure \ --header "Content-Type: application/json" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username: openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --header "If-Match: *" \ --request PATCH \ --data '[ { "operation" : "add", "field" : "/roles/-", "value" : "managed/role/Contractor" } ]' \ "https://localhost:8443/openidm/managed/user/0918e1ca-7d5e-473d-8b64-97f47cb606f6"

step.para: You can now review the entry for user jdoe on the OpenDJ server. Contrast this with the corresponding output shown earlier for user bjensen
step.screen: $ ldapsearch \ --port 1389 \ --hostname localhost \ --baseDN "dc=example,dc=com" \ --bindDN "cn=Directory Manager" \ --bindPassword - \ --searchScope sub uid=jdoe dn uid employeeType isMemberOf dn: uid=jdoe,ou=People,dc=example,dc=com uid: jdoe employeeType: Contractor isMemberOf: cn=Contractors,ou=Groups,dc=example,dc=com isMemberOf: cn=openidm,ou=Groups,dc=example,dc=com

step.para: You can also review other role-related elements for user jdoe, as specified by the entries after the _fields parameter.
By definition, a contractor is usually not a permanent employee. So you should know how to remove the Contractor role from users. In the output to the previous command, roles was shown as:
This array has two roles. Using "zero-based numbering," "openidm-authorized" is role 0 and managed/role/Contractor is role 1.

To remove the Contractor role, use the following command to point to and delete "field" : "/roles/1" from user jdoe. Note the _fields option at the end of the URL, which limits the output to the new value of roles.
step.screen:
$ curl \ --cacert self-signed.crt \ --header "Content-Type: application/json" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username: openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --header "If-Match: *" \ --request PATCH \ --data '[ { "operation" : "remove", "field" : "/roles/1" } ]' \ 'https://localhost:8443/openidm/managed/user/0e6bd1b6-2fa6-4029-a752-8264f1a09f72?_fields=userName,roles'
{ "userName" : "jdoe", "roles" : [ "openidm-authorized" ] }
step.para: As you can see in the output, the only role now assigned to user jdoe is openidm-authorized.
You can confirm the change with the following command:
step.screen:
$ curl \ --cacert self-signed.crt \ --header "Content-Type: application/json" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Username:openidm-admin" \ --header "X-OpenIDM-Password: openidm-admin" \ --request GET \ 'https://localhost:8443/openidm/managed/user?_queryFilter=/userName+eq+"jdoe"&_fields=userName,roles,effectiveRoles,effectiveAssignments'
{ "result" : [ { "userName" : "jdoe", "roles" : [ "openidm-authorized" ], "effectiveRoles" : [ "openidm-authorized" ], "effectiveAssignments" : null } ], "resultCount" : 1, "pagedResultsCookie" : null, "remainingPagedResults" : -1 }
step.para: Note how user jdoe is now assigned to only the openidm-authorized role, and has no effectiveAssignments.

procedure.title: Run the Sample Using the Admin UI

step.para: Log in to the Admin UI. If OpenIDM is running on the local system, the URL is https://localhost:8443/admin. The default administrative account is openidm-admin with password openidm-admin.
The first time you log into the Admin UI, you are prompted to change your password. If you do not want to change your password, click X to close this window, and continue with the sample.
Select the Mappings tab.
This tab shows two configured mappings, one from the ldap server to the OpenIDM repository (managed/user) and one from the OpenIDM repository to the ldap server.

mediaobject.alt: Mappings tab for the Roles Provisioning Sample

step.para: Click anywhere on the first mapping and click Reconcile Now.
The reconciliation operation creates the two users from the LDAP server in the OpenIDM repository.
Select Roles in the top navigation bar. This should open the Role List window.
Select Add Role. A New Role window should appear. Enter information as shown for the Employee Role.
Select Create. The Admin UI changes the name of the window to the Role Name, in this case, Employee. It also reveals three additional tabs: Events, Mappings, and Condition.
Select the Entitlements tab, and then Add An Entitlement.
The following image illustrates the attributes that you need to add to the attribute assignment named ldap. It is shown as an assignments in the output to the associated REST call:
To review the UI options for assignmentOperation and unassignmentOperation, select the Operations drop-down box, make any desired changes, and select Okay.
Select the Events tab. If desired, you can add custom Javascript or Groovy scripts. Since this sample works with default onAssignment and onUnassignment scripts, no changes are required here.

Select the Mappings tab. To synchronize the roles that you are creating, add the associated attribute assignment to the mapping(s) of your choice. Since this sample creates mappings in the OpenIDM Managed User repository, the mapping that you should add is managedUser_systemLdapAccounts.

Select the Condition tab. If you have a configuration where users have multiple accounts and you want to assign different roles to each account, you can specify Link Qualifiers as described in the following section:
Using Link Qualifiers in a Mapping. As that does not apply to this sample, leave it blank and select Save.

Select the Users tab. You should see reconciled users; if not, be sure to run the reconciliation operation described near the beginning of this procedure. For this sample, assign the Employee role to user bjensen.
Now create a Contractor role using the previous steps. You should be able to set it up based on the following REST output for the Contractor role.
If successful, you should see assigned roles and ldapGroups entries for both users bjensen and jdoe.

To review these entries, navigate to the Data Management UI. From the Admin UI, select the openidm-admin link in the upper-right corner of the page, and select Data Management View. When you see the Dashboard window, select Users in the top navigation bar, and select one of the two users (bjensen or jdoe). The following two screens illustrate the profile for user bjensen. Observe how that user has the Employee role and is shown as a member of cn=Employees in the linked LDAP account resource.
